A linear system is inconsistent if it has no solution, and consistent if it has either one solution or infinite solutions.
An elementary matrix is the result of applying an elementary row operation to the identity matrix.

ul.li: Interchange: Replacing one row with the other.
Multiplication: Each element in a row is multiplied by a non-zero $k$.
Addition: Replacing one row with the sum of itself and a multiplication of another.

post.p:
Gaussian elimination consists of applying these operations to the matrices (Formally, applying here means multiplying the matrix by the elementary matrix associated to that transformation) to turn the matrix into row echelon form, where we can tell whether it's consistent or not, and if it is, find its solution set.
A matrix is in row echelon form when:

ul.li: Every all-zero row is at the bottom of the matrix.
The leading coefficient of a non-zero row must be to the left of the one below it.
All entries below a leading coefficient are zero.

post.p:
(The leading coefficient of a matrix is the first non-zero entry in a row).
